Fields.DialogueText: What are you reading there?
Gah! Vy menya napugali!
Can I see it?
Da, Kapitan.
She was a fan of alexandrite? I suppose the wordplay opportunities alone could've been a selling point.
As to the mineral - according to some accounts it was her favorite.
Huh. I've never really thought of you as a jewelry person - but you obviously haven't had much of a chance in your life to shop.
Of course not. It would be wrong to consider such luxury above the needs of my countrymen, Kapitan.
I'm not sure buying jewelry automatically comes at their expense - but, fair enough.

Fields.MenuText: I don't know. A major review of inventory?
How about a performance check on each of the turbines? Nobody else could do the kind of job you can.
Take a look at the armor on the conning tower. See if any of it needs to be reinforced after the last couple of battles.

Fields.DialogueText: Konechno! I shall report back soon with what we need!
It's a good thought, Kapitan. I might take a look at the boilers as well.
How exciting! I shall report back soon.
That said... my report might need to be delayed. Enemy ships are inbound.
@BATTLE
What do you mean, Kapitan?
Um... anyway. This is an article about Tsarina Alexandra's jewelry. All very decadent, as you would expect.
Sorry. I wasn't actively trying to startle you.
No, no. I was just distracted.
Hm?
Alexandra, alexandrite? I mean, it... okay, never mind.
As you wish.
The metallic composition of the jewel makes it change color depending on the light source. The saying goes "Emerald by day, ruby by night."
If you'd like a shiny keepsake or two, I'm sure some of the crew would be happy to hit jewelry stores for you next time we're at port.
... Listen, don't take this the wrong way, but you've seemed kind of restless since your great reorganization of the storerooms a while back.
I certainly can't fault your overall performance, but... do you think you could use some new project? Something to keep you stimulated between battles?
I'm thinking of something like an efficiency review. We're obviously subject to some serious constraints when it comes to major upgrades or refittings...
... but you're uniquely qualified to look at how the ship is operating in aggregate and to suggest subtle improvements that could make a lot of difference.
Does that make any sense?
Da! I think so, at least. Where do you think I should start, though? It's not a small project.
Marat, you wanted to see me? Is this about the review?
Da, Kapitan. I've had an idea that should benefit the ship greatly.
Glad to hear it. What do you have in mind?
Deck prisms, Capitan.
Deck prisms?

Fields.MenuText: Doesn't that seem like a step back? Technologically?
Why not leaded glass?
You're still talking about ripping holes in our deck armor to bring secondary illumination to a very limited space. It's kind of an odd choice, isn't it?

Fields.DialogueText: Deck prisms can light a ship when electricity cannot, Kapitan. Still, illumination isn't the main point. I want to experiment with the radios.
Bohemia crystal should be the only leaded glass, Kapitan.
I think the atmospherics could have positive effects on morale, Kapitan. Still, illumination isn't the main point. I want to experiment with the radios.
*ALARM*
Would deck prisms help in a Morgana fog?
Quartz can turn the dimmest of light into a rainbow, Kapitan.
@BATTLE
Not just any ones either. We need ones made of quartz. In a pinch they can help repair any broken crystals in the radio communications.
I can't help but notice that you're staring intently at our maps. Looking for something in particular, or...?
Da, something particular - around the coast of China.
And what, exactly, is around the coast of China?

Fields.MenuText: Ah. Your deck prisms.
You're really hoping to upgrade that radio, aren't you?
Marat, maybe we should move on from the deck prism thing for a while.

Fields.DialogueText: Deck prisms would be wonderful, Kapitan.
Radios will improve our communications with other ships, Kapitan. We can stay ahead of events.
There is always cleaning, Kapitan. If you have time to lean, then you have the time to clean.
Okay. Okay, let me just make sure I'm following your reasoning here.
Deck prisms could also be lovely decorations.
Okay. If - if! - I agree to this, how many do we need?
Well, if we want something comparable to the Americans' new Hammarlund radio, then that takes six crystals cut at various sizes.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe quartz is more practical than I thought.
Let's try to just get an entire piece of equipment rather than parts.

Fields.DialogueText: Quartz has so many modern uses aside from decoration, Kapitan.
We will have to see what the ship has available. Let's not count our eggs before they have hatched.
How are you proposing to pay for all of this? The salvage ship, the...
This trip is being financed from the munitions we salvaged off of that fishing vessel we rescued during the storm.
... You have a slush fund.
Planning makes all the difference, Kapitan. It's why I'm confident our imminent battle with the Neizvestniy Flot will be a success.
Super.
@BATTLE
I'm hoping we can rendezvous with a salvage ship that might help us collect something useful.
Your hypothesis is that deck prisms will work so effectively as crystal detectors that you can build an electricity-free radio receiver comparable to, if not superior than, our current radio system.
Right.
Okay, here's my conundrum: we know pretty well how and why crystal radios work, and everything we know would suggest that this is basically folly.
And yet you're suggesting it. And you have powers and perceptions that I just don't.
And, moreover, you're talking about salvaging deck prisms from other ships rather than commissioning new ones, which suggests more Belle weirdness...
No offense.
None taken. Ne bespokoysya.
... which suggests more Belle weirdness that I'm not really qualified to evaluate.
Da. It must be very frustrating.
We have resources set aside to improve the ship's performance. Da.

Fields.MenuText: Why six?

Fields.DialogueText: Details, Kapitan. Don't get bogged down in them.
Marat, what are you doing with that map?
Da, Kapitan. And I approve. If the Soviet far east is being threatened by the enemy, my experiments can certainly wait.
So what are you focusing on? On the map, I mean.
Petropavlosk. I've always felt a connection to the place. Also... do you like caviar?

Fields.MenuText: I'd call it a guilty pleasure, but I don't actually feel that guilty.
I don't have enough experience with it to say one way or another.

Fields.DialogueText: That's the spirit, Kapitan!
Kapitan! This is something we need to correct!
South of Petropavlosk, you can find a selection of the finest caviar in all of the Soviet Union - and, by extension, probably the world.
Huh. Does the area have any sights to see besides fish eggs?
There are volcanos and bears, Kapitan.
I'll tell you more after we deal with this approaching problem.
Morganas?
Da, Kapitan. Remember, strategy is best accomplished when emotions are left at the door. Don't get too excited about our detour to Kamchatka.
@BATTLE
Ah. Kamchatka. You've heard about our detour, then?

Fields.MenuText: Not my thing. Not at all my thing.

Fields.DialogueText: That just means you haven't tasted the best the world has to offer, Kapitan. Trust me on this.

Fields.MenuText: I'd go so far as to call it invigorating.
Sorry. It's hard for me to be excited about being chilled to the bone.
Yeah. Sure. Exciting. Do you have anything to eat?

Fields.DialogueText: I agree, Kapitan! The crisp air always gives me a burst of energy.
Perhaps a drink might warm you up, Kapitan?
Maybe we can talk with a crabbing boat. Fresh crab with a bit of butter would sound very good right now.
When are we due for Kamchatka?
*ALARM*
That partly answers my question.
The sooner we can take care of the Neizvestniy Flot, the sooner we will be at that beautiful peninsula!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Now that was exciting.
That was too damn close.

Fields.DialogueText: Care to follow it up with a game of chess, Kapitan?
Perhaps we can strengthen our strategic skills with a game of chess?
I nearly forgot how much you enjoyed chess, Marat.
Honing strategy in one's spare time is a practical hobby to have, Kapitan.
Kapitan, isn't the cold sea air exciting?

Fields.MenuText: Once again our strategy wins the day.

Fields.DialogueText: Now that the immediate opponents have been dealt with... care to match wits on the chessboard?

Fields.MenuText: That's a volcano?
Very impressive. I hope it's dormant.
It's in the way.

Fields.DialogueText: Da, Kapitan. The neighboring volcano is Avachinskaya Sopka. When you stand on the peak of either volcano, you can see its sister.
Don't worry. The last major eruption was three thousand years ago.
That might be bad superstition to talk to a volcano like that. Her sister Avachinskaya Sopka might hear you!
Well, how are you going to do it?
Do what, Kapitan?
Don't beat around the bush. How are you going to get the caviar?
I'm afraid we're not going to port any time soon. Our patrol schedule is too rigorous - even without spectacular volcano views to distract us.
I'll just have to send someone off the ship to get some.
With what money?
I have some valuable items to trade.
But if you trade now, that's less to trade for upgrades later.
You are right, Kapitan. The needs of the crew come first. No caviar until after China.
I am sorry.
It is what it is. Sometimes life is a never ending, uphill battle... such as right now.
@BATTLE
Look how beautiful Koryaksky Volcano looks over the bay, Kapitan! Bal'zam na dushu.
The sea is a bit rough... How much farther until we rendezvous with your salvage ship, Marat?
I hope to make contact soon, but I can't make guarantees. As the saying goes, you cannot rush perfection.
We're trading in sayings, then? How about "time is money?"

Fields.MenuText: Heh. Point taken.
Perfect, cheap, and fast can happen if you have enough power.
I am out of ideas.

Fields.DialogueText: I am glad to hear that we have come to an agreement, Kapitan.
But then would it be perfect, and at the cost of those working?
Why don't we sharpen that wit with a game of chess, Kapitan?
What happens if this ship doesn't have what you're looking for?
Are you asking if that would be the end of my project?
More or less.
I'm not sure. We've come a long way just to give up - but the journey we've had might have been worth the effort all on its own.
That's something we can only judge once it's over.
*ALARM*
Perfect timing - something a little less existential.
Otlichno skazano!
@BATTLE
Perfect, cheap, and fast, Kapitan. Pick two combinations out of the three choices given.
It's really a question of how much trouble they've had on their trip north to meet us, Kapitan.
Look what I have, Marat! It's not caviar, but it might be just as good.
What are they, Kapitan?
They're called baozi. Take a bite and see if you like them.
We have these in the Soviet Union! Pirozhki - meat filled buns. This is delicious!
How would you compare these to caviar?
I am not entirely sure... I've never had caviar before.

Fields.MenuText: Then how do you know you would even like caviar?

Fields.DialogueText: It's hard to explain. I know I will like it because it is popular where my ship was laid down.
Switching subjects - do we have our trade goods loaded up and ready to go? When we meet that salvage ship I don't want to dawdle.
*ALARM*
Maybe this will have to wait, Kapitan. The salvage ship is one of the most efficient out there. We need to put an end to the Neizvestniy Flot before they put an end to it.
@BATTLE
We're almost ready, Kapitan. I have an officer supervising the packing even as we speak.
Mmm!
Wait. What?
Huh. Okay, why not?

Fields.MenuText: I thought for sure you'd had it, from the way you talk about it.

Fields.DialogueText: Belle memories work differently from yours. We have rough knowledge of our namesakes and homelands, even if we personally haven't experienced them.

Fields.MenuText: Just when I think I've got you figured out, you throw me a curveball.

Fields.DialogueText: An apt metaphor, though I prefer thinking of it as a discovered check. One should always keep people guessing!
That's... a lot. So what's in the pile?
Some new pipe fittings, Kapitan, for we cannot risk having a leaking ship. There are also some new switches - and, yes, quartz!
Not full-sized deck prisms, then?
Ya ne znayu - I haven't checked yet. They're meant to be in this box.
Looks like a game board of some kind.
We can ask the officer that got the box. But... ah!
Is it enough? We may not be able to put into Tsingtao in the next few weeks, but I think we can arrange to have a few supplies delivered. It won't be salvaged, but...

Fields.MenuText: And I thought you only liked chocolate.
Maybe save some more for me next time.
How many of those crystals do we have, exactly?

Fields.DialogueText: I like many things, Kapitan. Though, now that you mention it, chocolate would be pure bliss right now.
Proper procedures must be taken for that, Kapitan. A request must be put in and approved when pirozhki are available.
We seem to have several pounds of galena and quartz, Kapitan!
*ALARM*
We can count our treasures later. Time to head on a new course, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
These should be enough for my experiments. But... I do hope we can get more of those pirozhki baozi.
So the trade is done? How did we make out?
See for yourself!
What... is this? Some sort of grid board that folds?
Here we are. Some quartz, some dark galena. There's an interesting blend of semi–conductive crystals in this box.
Kapitan, it turns out this mystery grid is indeed the playing field of a game. A strategy game.

Fields.MenuText: Well, I'll be. Now you can torture the crew with something other than chess.
But we're missing the pieces, right? Do you know what they look like?
I thought that might be it. It's a surprisingly deep game - I think you'd approve.

Fields.DialogueText: We just need to figure out how to play it now, Kapitan. I wonder if there are any books written about it, or if anyone in Europe plays it?
Nyet. I am hoping a book on the game can answer that for me.
You know it well?
It's a shame we didn't know to look for written rules before we crossed into the Indian Ocean. We may not have a chance to hit bookstores until we reach Europe.
Well, at least we can hone our tactical skills the old-fashioned way in the meantime.
@BATTLE
In Japan it's called "go." In China, "weiqi." I'm told it's ancient - and very popular in East Asia.
I've played it a time or two - but you wouldn't want me for a teacher even if I had time to teach.
Heh. I just wish the Morganas could hear how bored you sound.
*ALARM*
Kapitan, do you know Edward Lasker?
Hang on. The name's familiar, but... wait, the chess player?
He wrote a comprehensive book about go - "Go and Go-Moku."
Ah.
He's German, right? We may be able to track down a copy on our way to the Baltic.
Otlichno. I didn't even have to ask!
And, hey, maybe this is why the game is called "go." In order to figure out how to play it, you have to circle halfway around the world.

Fields.MenuText: I thought that just went without saying.
Honestly, it probably would've been easier just to write our own book.
If we can get a message out soon, maybe we can have a copy waiting for us in Bremerhaven.

Fields.DialogueText: Sometimes the simplest things are most difficult to uncover. Analytical sorts like us thrive on patterns.
Ah, but what sort of game would you teach me to play?
I am excited to see where this path leads.
*ALARM*
We know the rules to this game, at least. If we can stay one move ahead, we will crush their egos, Kapitan.
Do the Morganas even have egos to crush?
You might be on to something, Kapitan.
Da!
I don't know him personally, obviously, but I guess I know who you're talking about.
Yeah, well - there are benefits to being predictable.
It's a fun story to weave, whether they do or not. And if they do, we're doing splendidly!
@BATTLE
Marat, what's wrong? You look... defeated.

Fields.MenuText: That doesn't mean we can't get our hands on the book.
Story of my life!
In hindsight, I really wish we'd known to look for a book back in China.

Fields.DialogueText: True enough, Kapitan. I'd hoped the association could help track down a copy, but there are other routes to the same goal.
That is terrible news, Kapitan! Perhaps you must think one move ahead.
I cannot read Chinese, Kapitan. I would have to find a translation to German, French or Russian - and would it even be a correct translation?
What about Herr Bookwriter himself? Do we know where he is? Maybe if you wrote directly...
Nyet, Kapitan. He seems to have moved out of Germany altogether. The crew and I and trying to trying to track him down, but....
*ALARM*
Looks like that dream will have to wait.
Yest'!
@BATTLE
I had hoped to make contact with the German go association...
Nyet, Kapitan. Only frustrated.
There's a German go association?
It was founded in 1937. But now, with the war...
Ah.
I have just learned that "Go and Go-Moku" was published in New York in 1934. And I believe that Mr. Lasker currently lives in the United States.

Fields.MenuText: ... You're going to ask me to look for some convoy escort assignment that'll take us to the States, aren't you?
Well, that puts us right back where we started.
I might ask you to pass along a few harsh words to your sources for neglecting that point until now. No offense.

Fields.DialogueText: You make it sound almost unreasonable.
We cannot give up, Kapitan. We must succeed at getting this book. Think of the story you will have to tell.
Da, Kapitan. Ya polnost'yu ponimayu.
I don't suppose you have any leads on this book that wouldn't require us to cross the Atlantic?
I am continuing to investigate, Kapitan. We might be able to get a copy of the book now that we know who the publisher is.
Well, that's something.
I also learned that Mr. Lasker invented a mechanical breast pump back in the `20s. It's apparently done wonders for infants born prematurely.
... I'm not sure I have a coherent response to that.
So. Our current patrol will take us back through the English Channel, Kapitan. Perhaps we can reach out to friends in London and find a copy of the book there.
To England, then.
But it seems that we have an obstacle to clear away first.
@BATTLE
Kapitan?
At ease, Marat. What's going on?
Huh. Okay, that...
And, actually, has done so for decades.
I mean, it's very impressive, obviously, but...
Never mind. Moving on.
You do not share my anatomical curiosity?
Crew, move along! We are under attack!
@BATTLE
Marat, are you eating ALL of that food?
Pochemu ty tak udivlen? It's just a full breakfast, Kapitan.
I'd call that a full breakfast for twelve. Are you going to have any room for lunch or dinner?

Fields.MenuText: Fish and chips.
Bangers and mash.
Don't ask. All the choices are English.

Fields.DialogueText: Fish and chips sound good, Kapitan. Don't skip on the malt vinegar.
I see. What is a banger, Kapitain?
You should fuel up your body anyway, Kapitan. Fueling your body can power the mind.
That's not too far. Are you the officer who... where did you go?
He just does that, Kapitan. At times I think he's faster than I am.
Wait. Chocolat?
... I mean the book, Kapitan... and maybe some chocolate. Best to get it while we are there and not waste the opportunity.
Oh, what's for dinner? I need to be at my top performance to find this book, and that requires a full stomach.
Just a sausage. As I understand it, the nickname came from a tendency toward exploding when being cooked.
Then I think I'm happier not asking about "mash."
Regardless - with your permission, I'll arrange for a detour to Calais. The sooner we are in France, the sooner we can get the chocolat.
Bystro! The faster we win, the faster we can rest and return to our tasks!
First Comrade? Our sources in London couldn't find a copy of the book you're after - but they were told there's a copy in Calais.
What do you see out there, Marat?
I wish I could see more of it. With Dover, you could at least make out the castle from the sea.

Fields.MenuText: We're not a day late and a ruble short?
Thank you, Offi- he's gone again.
Congratulations, Marat. I hope you actually like the game.

Fields.DialogueText: Our persistence has paid off, Kapitan. Be faithful to the crops and they shall yield the harvest.
Places to go, things to do. You understand.
Spasibo. Even if I do not, I've enjoyed the hunt.
What's that underneath the book?
Oh, this box? It's something I need to put with my gear, Kapitan.
Ah. You did get chocolate, then?
Da, Kapitan. If you want to taste it, we can send someone to go get more.
And now I have some insight into why the officers flee half a second after they report to you.
Enough of that. I have a book to read!
*ALARM*
Right after we take care of priority number one.
I wonder if any strategy from this book would be topical.
@BATTLE
It's finally here!
Calais. It's lovely.
Pah. I'm sure it's because you intimidate them.
First Comrade? Your delivery has arrived.
Son of a-!
Chto sluchilos'? Are you all right, Kapitan?
I'm fine, I'm fine - I just wasn't expecting the floor to be covered in bottle caps when I came in.

Fields.MenuText: I am. Didn't stop my foot from taking a cap for a spin.
It's too hot in this ship to wear shoes.
Don't ask the question if you won't like the answer.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah. Well, please be careful where you walk - it would be a shame to have to break in a new kapitan if you took a bad fall.
The boiler is currently being upgraded with the parts we acquired off of that salvage ship. It might be hot in here a little while longer.
... Now I'm intrigued.
So why are there bottle caps all over the floor?
These are pieces you use to play go, Kapitan.
And what have you learned about actual gameplay?
Black goes first. Stones are placed in the crosses of the grid, not the grid squares. The goal is to box in or outright capture the other player's pieces.
And you know how to start a game, I'm sure.
Da. There are zero stones on the board to start with, and each player takes a turn placing a stone on the board. It's really quite simple.
*ALARM*
I'll have to get back to the book later.
Clean up this mess first, Marat.
No time, Kapitan - our priorities lie with defeating the Morganas!
@BATTLE
Why aren't you wearing your shoes, Kapitan?
Well, it doesn't have to be bottle caps. It's usually flat pieces of stone or glass.
But these get the point across. I've painted one set white and one set black, and that's all you really need.
You still haven't cleaned this stuff up? You?
I think learning how to be effective in this game will help us strategize in the war, Kapitan.
Okay. I'm interested. Talk to me about go strategies.

Fields.MenuText: Well, I find it fascinating how thoroughly this is keeping you occupied.
Okay, I have to ask. Why not use stones instead of bottle caps?
What are your plans with this game?

Fields.DialogueText: I live for the challenge, Kapitan.
Stones might be hard to replace at sea. Bottle caps, not so much, given the current state of our inventory.
To become very effective at winning. It might be a useful skill to have.
Hm.
I would have. Actually, I wonder if there are any underground clubs still playing in Germany.
Have any new strategic insights to see us through?
Unless you are the fastest or most heavily armed ship in the fleet, strategy, skill and perseverance are your three best friends.
@BATTLE
And right now I'm spending a lot of time thinking about the utility of strings. Set pieces in a line, and they are defended.
Marat, are you feeling okay?
Ya v poryadke! Just preoccupied. Thank you, though.
Well, obviously, the lack of chess-like constraints at the beginning of the game means a great deal of thought needs to go into placement of your first pieces.
From the start, you must visualize where you can set your traps, you see?
Mm.
It's just fascinating. To me, at least.
I'm sorry the German association wasn't available to help you out. It sounds like you would have enjoyed the exchange.
But for now... the game will have to wait once again. Morganas are headed in our direction.
That last round really did some damage. Where are you, Marat?

Fields.MenuText: That's all I need to hear.
Anything I need to know?
How are we on medical supplies?

Fields.DialogueText: Da, Kapitan. It is always critical to help out when needed.
I've been thinking about go in Germany, but that will be shared with you another time.
We can always stock up on more, Kapitan. I'm afraid we can never have too much.
Fair enough. I'll leave you to it. You know where to find me if-
Oh! Wait - I have some interesting news, Kapitan!
Does it have to do with injuries?
Nyet, Kapitan. I've discovered that, like chess, go can be a high-stakes game.
You can make money by playing it?
You can make money at many games, Kapitan. Poker, baccarat, pool, horse racing... any place where people decide to "make it interesting."
Okay. Good.
In Europe? Probably not - and what's there may be underground. But there is also the United States. And Asia, obviously!
What about the language barrier?
Money speaks all languages, Kapitan. The barrier might be a good extra level of added difficulty, but Go has the same rules no matter the country.
Right. I'm... not sure where this is headed.
Right now we must be headed towards the Neizvestniy Flot  - they're almost in range.
@BATTLE
I am helping in the sick bay, Kapitan. Can you hear me?
Point taken. I should ask - you're not supposed to be helping to set broken bones while we talk here, right?
Oh, nyet!
But anyway, surely there aren't a lot of big-money go tournaments in the West right now. Given, you know, the war.
We haven't talked at all about the legality of betting on games onboard - if that's where you've been going with all this.
Maritime law is what it is. Because I am registered to the Soviet state, even in international waters I'm bound to the rules of my homeland.
No casino night, then.
Da, Kapitan. However, no laws preclude playing the game itself. Pigs will fly when the Soviet Union bans chess - and this is functionally no different.
Right. It's just that no money can be wagered.
Da, Kapitan. Except...
This should be good.

Fields.MenuText: How do you know so much about maritime law?
This seems... dodgy.
I'm obviously not going to divert us from our patrols for this. But if you can make it work, more power to you.

Fields.DialogueText: When one lives at sea, one should know what the rules are, Kapitan.
Again, maritime law is what it is.
I am glad you understand, Kapitan.
*ALARM*
We can't have the Morganas disrupt our plans. They will break under our perseverance.
@BATTLE
Suppose, hypothetically, we come alongside a ship which allows gambling. The actual wager could be placed on that ship, while the game would be played here.
Chert poberi!
What map is that in your hand?
A map of Australia, Kapitan!
Australia seems to be our best place to be, Kapitan. There are virtually no regulations on gambling, and it is not taxed either.
You've done your homework.

Fields.MenuText: What if you don't win?
What if that Edward Lasker shows up?
You've only just started playing the game - are you sure you can beat professional players?

Fields.DialogueText: Is that even a possibility, Kapitan? I will find a way to spin victory from defeat.
I would try to not be struck with nerves. I might need something to calm me down.
How else do you expect me to get better, Kapitan?
You really are something. You know that, right?
So, that's a "yes, we can go?"
I'll check and see if the mission is still available.
Zdorovo!
@BATTLE
Well, that's not entirely correct. Australia taxes gambling operations, so we would have to pay tax. However, it would all be legal then.
Okay, I'm not sure how you knew there was a mission slot open for us in Australian waters - but there is.
I haven't volunteered us for it yet, mind you.
You should!
This has something to do with gambling at go, doesn't it? To avoid just breaking regulations, you're prepared to sail literally halfway around the world.
... Da. Where are you going with that?
Never mind. Just tell me what you're thinking.
But do it after the battle.
I hadn't believed it was possible, but I think the weather's actually getting worse!

Fields.MenuText: Has our disappearing officer found something to hold on to?
I hope the ship doesn't get too battered!
Why do you suppose we do these crazy things?

Fields.DialogueText: Ya ne znayu. I do hope he's disappeared to somewhere safe, though.
I've survived worse, Kapitan.
Smile, Kapitan! Think of the story you will have to tell!
*RUMBLE*
I... think I just lost a scupper pipe. Don't ask me how.
Oh, that's going to be fun to fix in this weather.
It's fine. I'll give the crew a choice: play me at go or do the repairs. They should work without complaint.
*GROAN*
... Perhaps a small amount of complaint.
Ah, hell. See there? First things first.
@BATTLE
Everyone needs to hold on!
*THUNDER*
What's that noise?
You mean that sarcastically?
Oh, yes.
*ALARM*
Look at all that calm water. Isn't it fantastic?
Da. Fighting in storms is a welcome challenge - but it makes me have all the more appreciation for the calm sea.

Fields.MenuText: Please tell me you're not going to need a koala to add to your secret bear collection.
Actually, I know Australia pretty well - the occasional roo isn't going to feel all that exotic to me.
Looking forward to Australian food?

Fields.DialogueText: Technically, I think koala bears are part of the marsupial family. Real bears are not marsupials.
Do tell me more sometime, Kapitan!
Da. I hear there is a lot of grilled meat and fish, which is always lovely. Oh, and I want to try a "Witchetty grub!"
Is the scupper pipe sorted yet?
It feels pretty good, but I'll get official confirmation. Then I'll be off to practice go.
... After we take care of these Morganas, I mean.
Well, that's annoying. What's the point of a monster storm if it doesn't take out all the monsters?
Maybe they avoided the storm altogether?
Damn it, Marat. Nobody told me that was even an option.
@BATTLE
And we should be able to see Australia soon! I hope some of the more exotic animals play on the beaches so we can catch a glimpse.
I concede your point. And yet the proper response was, "No, Kapitan, I am not going to bring a wild animal on board."
Sorry. Ya beru na sebya polnuyu atvetstvenast'.
Yeah, yeah. Stop smirking and ready your guns.
*ALARM*
We'd better send out the invitations for the tournament.
I like the use of the word "tournament."
That's what it is, Kapitan - a regional tournament which invites international players. The fact that the prizes are significant is beside the point.
Are you going to send out the invitations by radio?
Nyet, Kapitan. My transceivers are all Soviet frequencies. We cannot risk that. We will send out the invitations by other means which can't be so easily deciphered.
Like mail?
Sometimes older technology has its advantages Kapitan. There is also word of mouth.
Do you think anyone will show up?
Da, ya uverena v etom. With the stakes involved, it can't fail.
How will you finance the stakes?
There's an entrance fee to play. After that, I start off with the easier players and work my way up. I leverage the winnings from the first player onto the more challenging one.
And if we lose?

Fields.MenuText: This seems sound.
How will we set up the tables?
How much notice are you giving to the players?

Fields.DialogueText: Spasibo, Kapitan. I've been trying to plan for every eventuality.
I'm sure that I will think of something clever, Kapitan.
As much notice as is required, Kapitan. Logistics is my middle name... or at least it should be.
*ALARM*
Oh, time to go take care of this little problem. We can't have the Neizvestniy Flot putting a dent in my logistics.
@BATTLE
That's why there's an entrance fee. Don't put all of your eggs into one basket, Kapitan.
What are all these crates doing here, Marat? It looks like a warehouse on deck.

Fields.MenuText: Doesn't that look a bit... industrial?
How much seating do you have up here?
So you have an Australian vessel lined up to handle the wagers?

Fields.DialogueText: Would you expect any different of me, Kapitan? They are here to play for blood, not watch a play.
More than we will need. I don't want it to look like I haven't planned enough for this.
Da! Of course!
How do they know where to find us?
I instructed them with vague directions to our general location and said, "You'll know my ship when you see it."
And you're expecting how many players?
I should think a minimum of five and a maximum of two hundred.
And you won't lose money if it's just five? Really?
We have other things to worry about first, Kapitan. Work must come before play.
Heh. What if the Morganas are just here to play in your tournament?
I'm afraid they're not going to make it past the qualifying round.
@BATTLE
We can use these storage and ammunition crates to serve as tables and chairs. The players will be here soon.
*ALARM*
Ready for battle! We have them in our pockets!
@BATTLE
There are so many people on this deck, I can hardly... ugh... move.
There is a special guest on board, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: Settle down and focus on the tournament.
Maybe have a recon talk with him to see what type of player he'll be.
Get me a drink too.

Fields.DialogueText: Da, Kapitan. I need to forget about Lasker's celebrity status and focus on the task at hand.
Good idea, Kapitan. I feel too nervous to go talk to him though. What will he think?
Is vodka a good drink, Capitan?
So... games are already being played, right? How do you become involved?
When the time is right, I'll start on the starboard side - over there - and work my way over to port. I'll have multiple games going at once, and just... work through them.
How many people are you playing?
The winners of the current hundred and twenty-five games - so sixty-two plus one, the odd person out.
... Are you insane?
Imagine all the Morganas we have fought together, Kapitan. Sixty-two plus one does not seem like such a large number.
The tournament is about to start. Time for me to go. If we win, think of all the upgrades we can use to our advantage.
Good luck, Marat.
Spasibo, Kapitan. Thank you for making this happen!
Did you hear, Kapitan? Herr Lasker himself showed up to the tournament. I don't know what I'm going to do. I think I need a drink to calm my nerves a bit.
Marat! Where are you!? Urrff. Where is Marat, Officer?
It was really just to distract you from the crystal radio plan, you know.
Ha! I'll get back to that one - you'll see!
